title: 114_s1989
content: The "Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015" allows for direct primary care service arrangements where individuals pay a fixed fee for ongoing primary care services. This arrangement is not considered a health plan or insurance. The amendment applies to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. The Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015 allows for direct primary care service arrangements with fixed fees for ongoing services. The Act also includes periodic provider fees as medical care and establishes a Medicare Primary Care Medical Home Demonstration Program. The Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015 allows for direct primary care service arrangements with fixed fees for ongoing services, including a Medicare Primary Care Medical Home Demonstration Program. Section 1115A of the Social Security Act is amended to include a Primary Care Medical Home Model reimbursing qualified practices for services provided to individuals enrolled under Medicare Part B. The Secretary will establish a periodic fee for qualified direct primary care medical home practices participating in the model under the Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015. The fee cannot exceed twenty percent of the estimated monthly amount payable for services under Medicare Parts A and B. The Secretary will establish a periodic fee for qualified direct primary care medical home practices participating in the model under the Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015. The fee will be based on performance benchmarks using ACO quality measures in the Medicare shared savings program. Starting from the second year of the model, practices that meet or exceed the performance benchmark will receive a periodic fee for each individual. The periodic fee paid to a direct primary care medical home practice will be increased by 5 percent for each individual meeting performance benchmarks, and reduced by 5 percent for those that do not meet the benchmark. The Secretary may terminate participation if the practice fails to meet the benchmark for 2 consecutive years. Each practice must offer specific services. Each qualified direct primary care medical home practice must offer preventive care, wellness counseling, primary care, coordination with specialty and hospital care, availability of ongoing care appointments 7 days per week, secure e-mail and telephone consultation, and a primary care provider panel size that supports the scope of services. Priority is given to direct primary care practices enrolling dual eligible individuals. Care provided in these practices is not considered insurance. Direct primary care medical home practices participating in the model are not considered insurance products and are not regulated as such by State insurance commissioners. These practices must report annually to the Secretary on the progress of individuals with chronic conditions, including emergency room visits, hospitalizations, surgeries, specialist visits, and advanced radiology use. Additional areas for reporting may be determined by the Secretary. The Secretary will provide qualified direct primary care medical home practices with necessary patient data for clinical purposes and evaluation of the model. Physicians who have opted out of Medicare may participate in the model and receive payment for services provided to Medicare beneficiaries under private contracts. The model under this subsection allows qualified direct primary care medical home practices to participate for a minimum of 3 years. Physicians excluded from federal health care programs cannot take part in this model. If a practice meets certain requirements after the third year, it can continue permanently. The model allows qualified direct primary care medical home practices to participate for a minimum of 3 years. If the practice meets specific requirements after the third year, it can continue permanently. If a majority of practices meet the requirements, the model will be expanded nationwide. SEC. 5. Use of direct primary care medical homes under the Medicare Advantage program allows Medicare Advantage organizations to contract with qualified direct primary care medical home practices for primary care services and shared savings agreements. Qualified practices are defined in the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act.
